name: cheese production, soft, from cow milk | whey | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/10833/documentation

There are a very wide range of cheese varieties and many subtle differences in processing methods. In general, however, the following process steps apply; production of coagulum through the action of rennet and/or lactic acid, separation of the resulting curds from the whey, and manipulation of the curds to produce the desired characteristics of the cheese.;;Classification of cheese according to firmness and ripening (FAO, 1978, Codex General Standard for Cheese);;This activity represents soft cheese production (mozzarella type).;The dry mass is not balanced in this inventory because the emphasis was put on fat content balance.;Source: European Comission, IPPC, 2006, Reference Document on BAT in the Food, Milk and Drink Industries

This boundaries of the activity are given by the physical boundaries of the creamery.

This activity end when the finished product - cheese - is ready to leave the gates of the creamery.
category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/105:Manufacture of dairy products/1050:Manufacture of dairy products

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset has been created mainly based on a study (Kim, D., et.al., 2013, Life cycle assessment of cheese and whey production in the USA) which collected data from 6 different creameries producing mozzarella. Each facility has a different size and technology. Thus this study is an average of different technologies of mozzarella production.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from the local, US dataset. The uncertainty data have been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: In total six mozzarella manufactoring facilities shared their data used to compile this LCI. The cumulative production of these factories is 0.35 million tons.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value based on literature (Kim, D., et.al., 2013, Life cycle assessment of cheese and whey production in the USA).

The whey produced in this process is 74.7% dry whey and 25.3% wet whey. The ratio between wet and dry mass dictates the amount of energy needed (for the drying).

exchanges.description:
Literature value (Kim, D., et.al., 2013, Life cycle assessment of cheese and whey production in the USA).

kg of Fat and Protein Corrected Milk. FPCM is 4.0% fat and 3.3% true protein content. Conversion to FPCM is as follow, according to the International Dairy Federation: FPCM (kg/yr) = Production (kg/yr) x [0.1226 x Fat% + 0.0776 x Protein% + 0.2534]

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data (Schmid, A.; 2010, Bachelor-Thesis; Carbon Footprint von Schweizer Käse, supervised by T.Nemecek, Agroscope).

20 years is the lifetime of a dairy
(18*10*3=) 540m3 is the volume of the dairy
2.2E6 kg/year is the amount of milk proccessed annually in the dairy of volume of 540m3.
